status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) Inspector investigated and determined the following:. National Grid posted your street for a request for a new service. We have told permittees when they post a street in Boston they must show up for the dates indicated on the sign. Parking is a premium and we acknowledge that is is frustrating moving your car and not having anyone show up. We understand that sometimes construction has unforeseen issues like equipment breakdowns, asphalt plants not available etc. resulting in not working the days posted. However we have told the permittees they must change the dates on the signs to reflect the new work dates. National Grid did start the work yesterday.  They will continue to show up every day until the work is completed. We apologize for the inconvenience you incurred. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

status_notes: Case Noted. This signal is designed in conformance with BTD Guidelines which specify a system of walk lights in conformance with federal safety standards and widely used through out the country.  Under this system it is possible to provide longer "Walk" times and shorter delays to vehicles and pedestrians.  During the green light for vehicles "Walk" signals are on for pedestrians crossing parallel to the flow of traffic.  Under this system turning traffic must yield to pedestrians.  We have verified that signs are in place directing turning traffic to yield to pedestrians and additional signs are provided to warn pedestrians to watch for turning vehicles.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) investigated and determined the following. Eversource Electric had an oil leak on its transmission line. This transmission line is critical for the power supply to South Boston. Eversource has been working ever since to rectify this critical situation. This was not planned work. They totally understand and regret the tremendous impact they are having on the residents near this work. That is why they flyered the neighborhood explaining the situation. They have had to place stationary work zones along the route of the repair. This is to protect the workers and the public. They have police details and Eversource Supervisors who are allowing residents access in and out. Public Works and the Transportation Department also understand the inconvenience to the South Boston residents for this necessary work and we also apologize. There is a 24 hour project hotline number 617-541-7634 if you needed something addressed right away. If you want to reach out to Eversource to discuss this matter further you can email John Hoey at John.Hoey@eversource.com. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

Today I was crossing the Masspike on Shawmut Ave and when I got to Marginal Ave. I noticed some women trying to push a lady in a wheelchair up out of the street onto the sidewalk, where there is no curb cut (Corner of Shawmut/Marginal across from

I've seen people struggle to get out of the street and onto the curb here before, as people walk their children to school every day with strollers in tow. Would you please add a curb cut to this sidewalk corner? 

Thank you for reading!!

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. Before the Public Works Department resurfaces any street in Boston it requires 22 utility companies and City Agencies to review the street to determine if they have any proposed utility work. If there is no proposed future planned work we require each entity to sign off that the street can be paved.  Once the street has been fully signed off the City does not want anyone to dig the street for a 5 year period.  We now call the street a Guaranteed Street. In order to have the most effective clearance review, Public Works created an online database that reserves construction work. The City of Boston Utility Coordination Software (COBUCS)  will not allow any construction work to take place until it has been entered into COBUCS. It has been a breakthrough for coordination and has alerted the City over 10,000 times at a savings of over $35 Million in paving costs. . Unfortunately either because of emergency work or the explosion of development we have had our guaranteed streets dug into.  It is frustrating but it also shows how vibrant and an attractive city Boston is that people want to expand their businesses or live in our City. If you cut into a guaranteed street you are required to restore the street 25 feet on either side of the cut. That is what you saw on Granger St. The City is not responsible for any of the costs.  It is strictly the permittee who applies for a guaranteed street cut waiver. I know it is a long explanation, but I hope it gives you a clearer picture.  For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951.
description: why is granger street being repaved?
